review_title: toxic work environment at all levels
pros: nice building and location, most floor have decent equipment
cons: Everyone is toxic and create their own group like high school, toxicity is floor staff to floorstaff, administration to staff, floor to floor if your not in their group your the enemy

review_title: The absolute worst hospital I've ever worked at
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Denver, CO
pros: The fellow staff nurses are amazing.
cons: This hospital is a complete mess. The management cares only about profits, not their staff and not their patients. Day shift nurses were pushed to 7 patients, TOTALLY UNSAFE!!! Then management has the nerve to knit pick small insignificant things the nurses did. They have a book they write down everything "wrong" you do and then make you answer for each incident. The culture is absolutely toxic and management seems to be completely soulless. It's no wonder this entire hospital is staffed by new grads and travelers. DO NOT GET FOOLED INTO A 2 YEAR NEW GRAD CONTRACT WITH THIS COMPANY! IT IS TERRIBLE AND WILL MAKE YOU HATE NURSING! Scl has a better atmosphere and treat their staff with respect, if you have to do a new grad program I'd go with them or centura.

pros: Great hospital, coworkers, and patients
cons: Definitely income driven like most hospitals

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Englewood, CO
pros: The people are absolutely amazing. Lifelong friendships. I love what I do but the current circumstances in the hospital made me leave.
cons: Management and the upper hand only care about profits. They don’t care about their employees or their patients. Nurses are required to work a mandatory on call shift once a scheduling period in addition to working full time. This was supposed to be temporary but has gone on for over 2 years. Unsafe patient ratios. No CNAs or secretaries. Nurses are expected to do the jobs of multiple roles. Expectations continue to grow but pay does not. They pay new grads about the same as nurses who have worked there for years and only slightly compensate you if you bring it up to them. Turnover is crazy. Everyone there is either 30 years in and about ready to retire or they’re all new grads. No in-between. I’ve seen it go more and more downhill over the years and finally had enough. Sadly, it’ll only continue to get worse unless they choose to do something about it.

review_title: To be expected with a for-profit hospital

cons: 1:6 patient ratios on most floors. Even card-surg is 1:5, always a staffing issue and have seen a nursing managers consistently have to take patients. But the CEO makes 15k an hour so at least he's making money to put up with this place

review_title: May not be worth the trouble to work here.
pros: Pay is good. A lot of education is provided. Transfer processes to other departments is relatively easy if you do not use HR.
cons:
HR is almost impossible to work with. I cannot express enough how many times HR could not/would not do what they needed to do. Other staff and I had to ask managers to accept us as transfers because HR would not put our applications through even though we qualified or already picked up shifts there. HR would incorrectly say we "did not meet qualifications". If applications did not use the EXACT wording HR expected, applications were rejected. 
Nurse managers were often unnecessarily callous and not pleasant or easy to work with. This type of attitude was an expectation for the role. Management used fear to control staff. No, not every manager was unpleasant, but the good ones were rare or didn't stay long.
After 6 years of working there, these were the 2 things I could count on.

review_title: Laboratory staffing dangerously low....Admin. aware with NO CHANGES to address this....
pros: Always quite busy, shift goes fast.  The transition to being managed by Quest Laboratory is seemingly accomplished after several years.. Long term laboratory employees really help stabilize the team with expertise and now have wildly fluctuating start times to compensate for reduced staff/increased workload  at all benches; a situation that corporate number crunching  has produced.  Butterfly usage is not limited.  HCA has managed to remain highly profitable when other hospitals are folding, and Swedish Lab has been a shining example to sister hospitals in terms of productivity.
cons:
Meditech is wasteful of our time. Time where every move is being monitored, productivity demands are unrealistic, ever-increasing, and ever stressful to many. 
Staffing is ridiculously low...and you are making huge profits on the backs of your people. Literally. Phlebs are being worked to death, several are out with serious medical issues and you provide NO real solutions.  Turnover at all time high, with management turning head away from some REAL NEEDS.

review_title: worst job I have ever had
pros: the only pro I can think of would be a handful of coworkers that made it bearable to come to work.
cons: Management is a joke, they don't ever have their employees backs and will throw them under the bus at the drop of a hat. They only care about one thing and that is money. They don't care about unsafe patient ratios with high acuity patients and no supportive staff at all. They pick on their new grads and punish them for mistakes instead of making it a learning opportunity to teach them. The environment was toxic and very "cliquey". They had a very distinct group of people that ran the floor and if they didn't like you they made things very uncomfortable for you. Staffing always depended on money and budget not what was actually safe for the patients. They would rather have their nurses 6-1 with no tech and save money than to bring in another nurse and lessen everyones load. If you tried to speak out about your concerns you then became a target and were pushed out. They aren't interested in anything that could take away from their profit, but are 100% fine taking things away from their staff. To put the cherry on the top, their pay is laughable compared to anywhere else.

review_title: Exceptionally hard working and committed employees
pros: Certainly the staff of SMC made it a good place to work.  I was continually impressed by the hardworking and committed staff - especially the tenured individuals that had been through a lot.  While I was there, they had an amazing concierge service for staff to utilize.  Great cafeteria that made not bringing breakfast or lunch way too easy.  SMC also had some neat cultural experiences unique to the hospital itself, as part of its history.
cons: SMC is part of the larger HCA conglomerate and they are driven strictly by profits.  Benefits continued to be reduced for staff and pay seemed to stagnate except when faced with a staffing crisis in certain departments.  A job in management or any salaried employee guaranteed especially long hours and extremely high expectations with little regard to work life balance.  The PTO for non-management, new salaried staff was also disappointing where your PTO included all holidays, sick time and regular vacation.  During the hiring process, try to negotiate PTO and better pay – it is unlikely you will be successful at a later time otherwise.

pros: I joined SMC about a year ago after having worked at both for-profit and not for-profit healthcare organizations. What a great hospital and organization!. They are committed to their patients and staff. Staffing ratios are very good with most med surg units running 1:4 on days and 1:5 on nights. Multiple layers of support have been built in including 24/7 charges, unit based educators, and now specific advanced practice nurses working each night of the week to support the nursing staff.  The leadership team is all about supporting the staff and making sure they have what they need. The quality of leadership in the organization is by far the best I have ever experienced. Also, this organization truly supports the shared governance model.  If you get the chance, to work at SMC Denver, run don't walk! It blows other organizations away.
cons: Meditech is cumbersome. It doesn't has the flexibility that some other EMR's have. But the clinical informatics team does a good job supporting the end users and adapting whenever possible.

pros: Multiple programs within Swedish to develop staff.  Every new nurse is provided with a plan for their individual growth and advancement.  Nurse leaders are very good - very competent.  I love my team members.  Free parking.  Decent access to public transportation (bus service picks up on campus).  Love the executive leadership - they seem to genuinely care about every staff member and our personal well being.  I also feel like they listen to our needs and try to satisfy them - if they can't, my experience is that they usually try to explain why.
cons: Parking can be a challenge - I know they are trying to fix it, but seems like its always a pain to find parking.  Workload can be a lot.  We are a big busy hospital - so bed capacity can be a challenge and trying to dc a lot of people at one time can be difficult.

review_title: Great people but the heart has been lost
pros: I have made some of the best relationships of my life under the Swedish Medical Center roof. It is also what has kept me there longer than what was best for me. I would still go as a patient knowing the quality of care is strong with the stroke team and critical care teams.
cons: With the HCA overhaul, a 'profit over people' environment has become a lot more pronounced. It is a very 'top heavy' company where administrators and the C suite are generously compensated when the worker bees/clinical staff are paid 90-105% of the market average (meaning, at best- employees are making just over average).  Of course when this information is delivered to employees, it is spun in a way to make people feel they are paid in the 90th+ percentile of market average. Management is not transparent and unfortunately the soul of the hospital has been lost over the years.

review_title: Worst Corporation in history of U.S.
pros: They have discontinued and/or destroyed any that once existed.
cons: All they care about is profit.  This translates to demanding more work from fewer employees,  strictly punitive management, erosion of benefits, and declining morale., to name a few of its adverse effects.  It was a great hospital and workplace until Columbia took over in 1995. Then it went downhill overnight and has continued to landslide to what has to be an all-time low; from what was like a big happy family to the workplace with the lowest morale I have ever encountered or imagined.  They talk the talk but they don't walk the walk. It's all for show but it doesn't take long to see how transparent and phony they are.

pros: Great place to work.  Co-workers are amazing.  The benefits are truly great.  The prescription coverage is truly amazing.
cons: The pay is less than enough to live alone and under the cost of living.  The 3% increase is what they say is for the cost of living increases, but the cost of living here is increasing almost 7% each year.  Understaffed and underpaid.  To keep nursing staff the minimum starting wage for nurses should be at least $35/hr

pros:
Good benefits, stock options, and 401k matching. There are some long term employees in the lab with a lot of valuable experience and knowledge. Phlebotomy supplies are well stocked. 

Employees are welcome to share their thoughts during meetings and on surveys. Management tries to fix issues that they can (their hands are tied though). Tyler H (corporate) has pushed for real changes to help us.
cons:
The productivity standards (which the lab doesn't control) are unrealistic and often dangerous. 

We're told the lab is "fully staffed" but routinely only have two phlebotomists/lab assistants per shift on evenings and nights. This is half of what is truly needed (they have other duties on top of drawing!) and causes the nurses and doctors to become angry with the lab, which increases already sky high stress levels. 

The blood bank in a level 1 trauma center should never have only one employee. If an emergency arises they can call someone in, but by the time they get there it can be too late.

Med techs running the tests are stretched thinner and thinner. Fast turnaround times are important, but without enough people they can lead to shoddy work and taking shortcuts. The demands fly in the face of the HCA mission statement ("Above all else we are committed to the care and improvement of human life"). The company may make an extra nickel but it is bought by grinding employees down and sacrificing quality patient care.

pros: Very good teamwork and connection between staff at all levels. New management has brought fresh ideas with focus on better connections to our bedside staff. Many new hires that have been great additions to our team. Future looks bright.
cons: Lots of change in nursing in general with many new faces. Need to continue to focus on listening to the needs of staff and proactively responding.

review_title: ER was great place to work
pros: Great management, great teamwork environment and worked with some amazing nurses there. Would definitely go there as a patient if I had an emergency.
cons: Can be a little inflexible regarding schedule changes, they changed one of my days to a really inconvenient start time without speaking with me about it first, just sent me an email telling me about the permanent schedule change. Took about a year to get the shift I wanted.

review_title: Do not work here or for hca
pros: very easy to get hired! The staff is nice and for the most part hard working. Doctors are super nice.
cons: All hca cares about is making money! They force us to budge everyday and work short staff to save money. 2 weeks after I got off orientation they had me charge on night shift when I had zero charge exp and when I brought my concerns to management they did not care until I threaten to go to HR and quit. You are micromanaged and threaten to be wrote up for everything down to not having your name written on the white boards.

pros: Frontline staff are amazing and dedicated.  The food (cafeteria) is decent and reasonably priced. The building has electricity and modern plumbing. (There is a 20 word minimum here. LOL)
cons: Talented and longtime staff are leaving in droves. Recent leadership changes have been disastrous. Staffing has become dangerously low. Middle and upper management don't know or care about frontline staff, decisions made based only on profitability. Pay is ridiculously low, recognition is nonexistent.

review_title: This is without a doubt the worst place I have ever worked.
pros: Weight loss due to constant running and no opportunity to take a lunch break.  Great coworkers but they don't stay long.
cons: Short-staffing, unsafe nurse-patient ratios, punitive atmosphere, bosses openly talk bad about employees by name, bosses follow you around and go through your stuff daily to try to catch any mistake, not enough help on the floor, don't have needed equipment, focus on profit above all else - screw the employees, docs, patients - and forcing staff to take patients they aren't trained for, high turnover, employees are not listened to

review_title: They don't care about the patient.
pros: Pretty much anybody can be hired so if you're looking to get your foot in the door this works well. Especially good for medical school applications.
cons: Little pay for the amount of work and responsibilities. You have to monitor the patients heart rate, oxygen, it's, you name it and I walk about 8 miles a shift so $11 an hour doesn't cut it.

review_title: Went downhill during my time there

cons: Managers tend to tow the line instead of sticking up for nurses, felt little appreciation by upper management in spite of doing hard work, did not feel as though nursing managers had my back

review_title: Don't judge the book by your interactions with HR; once I got through the HR process I am extremely happy in my decision

pros: Unit manager, unit staff and teamwirk and suppoet,  acuity, unit education and professional support overall from unit manager
cons: Meditech EMR, HR paperwork/ follow up.

pros: The frontline are great, even though there is little support for Senior Leaders
cons: Micromanaged to the extreme.  New CNO is obsessed with documenting every conversation that is had with staff.  Spend more time on documenting and auditing, leaving no time for patient care or what is important.  It has become a very punitive environment, what is done wrong is what is pointed out and staff are very frustrated.

pros: There are some good people working there, coffee shop nice on ground floor open on nights. There are parking garage that’s free. There is 20 word minimum.
cons: It is not a good place to start as a new grad. They expect  new grads to be able to take 4 patients first day. There is five weeks of orientation, and if you ask question it will count against you. The nurses are very catty and back stabbing, this place is an example of how nurses eat there young. Dangerous staffing ratio 1:8 and not enough techs to help out 1:20. Patient are charged everything down to the toothpaste. They only care about money not about safe patient care. Very high turnover, nurses are given scripts on how to talk to patients because all they care about hcahps which is low to begin with. If you are robot and no sense of self this is a great place for you. There is no support for nurses, and they will write you up for any little mistake. If you want to be a refreshment and narcotics nurse, This is the place for you. Computers in the medication room doesn’t work, have to write down all medications. They only care about the money and do not support their nurses. They also use Meditech, which sucks. They say it was new and improved Meditech but is something out of the 80s. They’re too cheap to buy Epic, which probably will improve their patients satisfaction scores and medical errors. Doctors are extremely rude to staff and treat them dirt.  They have an extremely high turnover rate, they pay the worst out of all hospital systems in Denver.  The benefits suck, $1200 each month. Stay far far away from this hospital. Highest needlestick incidents in the country. They also use the cheapest equipment and supplies. My advice is to stay far far away from this hospital and HCA/HealthOne.

review_title: Wonderful organization to work for. Excellence is supported by management.
job_title: Staff RN-Cath Lab in Englewood, CO
pros: Excellent support from immediate management.This is a "for profit" hospital and so they have to meet their bottom line. Very cost effective.
cons: Called off for low census often.Was only able to work in another area once when being called off due to low census.

pros: I get a paycheck, management tries to understand the issues
cons: Compensation is not competitive, bureaucracy stacked on bureaucracy, benefits are contingent on jumping through a lot of hoops. It's skewed toward attracting doctors, not keeping support staff.

job_title: Health Information Specialist in Englewood, CO
pros: Vary patient care driven environment;
cons: Unless your involved in direct patient care, i.e., RN, MD, Physicians etc. there not much to do  overtime to earn more money; No yearly bonuses/incentives for employees- when the hospital network as a whole, accomplishes big achievements the employees should also be compensated for their hard work and efforts.

job_title: ER Patient Registrar in Littleton, CO
pros: I like that it's a fast pace environtment, and I like my schedule of 3 12 hour shifts
cons: The pay with HCA is not very competative and the mangagment is HORRIBLE!

review_title: HORRIBLE pay and benefits and extremely disorganized

cons: none for me I don't know about everyone else

review_title: My experience as a CNA at Swedish was absolutely terrible!!!
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Englewood, CO
pros: There are no pros here.
cons: There were so many cons working at Swedish it's hard to list them, but the biggest ones were pay and patient ratio. I wasn't even making $12 an hour when I worked there and I had 20 patients all to myself on the progressive care unit. It is a big safety issue having only one person for a whole floor.

review_title: Incredible leadership and clinical staff in the Respiratory Therapy dept.
pros: Directors, Coordinators and RT staff very skilled,  approachable, knowledgeable and professional.
cons: None that I can think of really. It's a very budget conscious organization but I can't think of any in healthcare that aren't so it's just the norm.

job_title: Social Worker/Case Manager in Edmonds, WA
pros: Almost every other single physician and employee is wonderful to work with.
cons: Management is predatory and intends to work their employees to death without purpose. It's a business model to break the union and the power of employees.

pros: The pay is okay for this area. Management on my unit is fantastic and so are my colleagues.
cons: Providence has taken over Swedish and has put profits before patients and staff. We are always understaffed and being asked to pick up overtime which is exhausting.
